channel.title: Programming courses at university
channel.description:
I'm looking at the programming courses that I can take at university, and there are two in particular I want to go for, and after reading the course overview, I'm still not sure as to which one I want to go into and would appreciate some information if anyone has anything to share. The two courses I'm looking at is Computer science, and Computer games programming.
I'm currently taking a computing course at college, but it's nowhere near what I want to do. The programming is at an extremely basic level, with iteration being the most "complex" task and on top of this, its main focus is on the theory work, which makes up the 3 hour exam which I absolutely hate.
I'm interested in games programming, AI etc and this really interests me as this is what I've always wanted to do but I've been given advice to take computer science to understand programming more. The problem with this course is the fact that it uses different languages as I believe they're better for games programming, direct x etc, so it's going to be using c++ and I've never even touched that language.
I just want to focus on the programming to be honest, gain new skills, get more fluent and that's what I enjoy, but if Computer Science contains all of the theory work, like user requirements, system design, testing and development etc (Writing up...) then I really don't want to take it, even if the course does focus on Java as it's main language.
Any advice on the two courses? (Sorry if this is the wrong section)

item.title: Programming courses at university
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:27, topic:538963”][quote author=matzie link=topic=657798.msg4411130#msg4411130 date=1393742473]
To get those Higher level courses you will need to attend a 4-year rather than a 2-year college. Not many community colleges offer such courses. Odds are the first class your taking is Introduction to programming (a level 100 course) and next is a 200. 200 will get you into Some things like GUI’s and other simple graphical things. Ours we made Pong, and are working on O(n) for sorting techniques. odds are had you done some basic programming before, you could of skipped your level 100 course by going to the professor and explaining you already know the basics. They would probably have you write a simple program, or have you explain a bit of code to them.
[/quote]

If this was aimed at me, this is pretty much what it’s like now. We write a simple system and have to do a write up of it. The typical degree is the 3 year, which is probably the first year being introductory as they teach it from the ground up and then progresses in the second and third year. There is another option which allows for a 4th year, which would be a placement year with a games dev company, so I might take this option. Was suggested before it’s good for experience.[/quote]

I also suggest you keep a solo game project in development all through your college years. You never know if you game will blossom into some multi-million dollar game idea, like Mojang’s Minecraft. or Banished(unknown creator). Banished was entirely written by one person in a basement, except for the music.

item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“0xCAFEBABE, post:22, topic:538963”]Taharok:

It seems like the term “Computer Graphics” also refers to image processing.

Here is a quote from Wikipedia:

Computer graphics is a sub-field of computer science which studies methods for digitally synthesizing and manipulating visual content. Although the term often refers to the study of three-dimensional computer graphics, it also encompasses two-dimensional graphics and image processing.

The link is here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_graphics_(computer_science)

Now you might argue that you shouldn’t quote Wikipedia. But, what’s written there is correct the most of the time.

Edit: By the way, filtering is also part of realtime rendering. For instance, in texture mapping, bilinerar interpolation and bilinear filtering is the same thing.[/quote]

Alright then. I stand by what I said in the absurdity that computer graphics “has nothing to do with” game development, though. Tons of graphics hardware is progressed specifically because of game development and non-realtime rendering.

item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:21, topic:538963”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=657798.msg4405651#msg4405651 date=1391901023]
Just to clarify, computer graphics as I’ve mentioned it has nothing to do with game development. It’s processing imagery for the purpose of computer vision, among other things.
[/quote]

Uhhh, that’s image processing, not computer graphics. The are entirely different fields of study. Computer graphics is the means of rendering and processing image data in real-time, whereas image processing has to do with things like edge detection, filtering, etc. Modern server clusters can do a lot of complex image processing algorithms in real-time, but they are still radically different in intention to computer graphics.

Computer graphics inherently does not have to be linked to game development or CGI in general, but it has a ton to do with both.[/quote]Yeah no mate, he’s right that is computer graphics - we have the same course here. Stop trying to be pedantic.

item.title: Programming courses at university
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:18, topic:538963”]It’s silly to choose a degree as specific as game development in my opinion.
Computer science, at least in Australia, covers quite a large amount of low-level computing (I’m talking embedded systems such as robotics and machinery controllers, among other things). At least at my university it also involved things like computer graphics, AI, security, etc. Plus there’s the maths component, which is quite important.

I did IT instead of computer science but, frankly, I wish I did computer science and just worked hard to get through the maths.[/quote]

Not if that’s what you want to do. Some schools that specialize in Computer Science, e.g. DigiPen, focus on this:

0xCAFEBABE:

I never got a real CS degree (i also never took a game development course), and yet I have worked as a game developer (at the same project as Jeb). My CV was what mattered for me, though. That, and being extremely passionate about what you do, will get you a long way. Just because you have a degree usually doesn’t mean that much, which a lot of people seems to think. It may help you get further in the selection process. But once you’re one of the few selected, you have to stand out, by showing off what you have done in your spare time. The closer your projects are to what they are looking for, the better chance you will have.

Schools that force you to do game projects and learn how to work with people are excellent for helping to get into the game industry. They also work really, really well to get into any other industry, too. Now a school that just slaps a few graphics classes onto a CS degree and calls that game programming, that’s completely absurd. That’s not how we do things.

Rodgerwilco:

If you’re serious you should intern at the company that you’re interested in (while going to college if you can) You may be the coffee runner for a few months but it’s a great way to get connections. I did an intern at Dreamworks and it was a great opportunity to realize that was the path I did not want to take but also hooked me up with connections.

I agree with this. Internships are a really great way to build professional experience and expand your professional network. Consider creating a linked in profile; they’re more useful than you’d think.

item.title: Programming courses at university
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:4, topic:538963”]CS will teach you the basics of game programming.

I’ve heard of people with a CS degree working in game programming jobs, but never a game programming major working in a CS related job.

Most CS degrees offer game programming as a specialist stream anyway.

for what it’s worth I am currently studying computer science, but I plan on taking the Data and Mathematics specialist stream.[/quote]

You must not know any game programmers. Game programming is part of the CS degree field. Pretty common to switch between the different fields.

@OP: it’s not as simple as going into CS and “specializing in game development.” That’s silly. Game development is an entire industry of development in itself, with a wide variety of job paths. Some parts are extremely difficult if you’re into more cutting edge solutions (this also applies to other fields of CS that big tech companies tend to have to solve), otherwise there’s tools programming in game development which is super similar to general CS. There’s also gameplay programming which is more of what I consider true “game programming,” but that’s neither my interest nor my forte, so I’m not going to discuss it much.

Just take various courses and see what interests you. There are schools and graduate programs that specialize in certain tracks, including game development, AI, graphics programming, networking, systems engineering, etc. The field is absolutely monolithic. Just look around and take a class that’s interesting.

item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

I wouldn’t expect much from any low-level programming course unless it’s from a large University with an actual professor teaching it. (Not a TA.)

Out of 3 programming classes I’ve taken, I’ve known more than the person teaching the class in at least 2 of the 3 cases. (The 3rd probably knew more, just judging by her having worked for IBM/Intel.)

Those other two professors just spouted random nonsense that they weren’t even sure of, one didn’t know the bit size of a double in Java (Java was the subject of the class), and one started teaching output for a C++ class using printf, which is C.

Make sure you’re not wasting your money (check ratemyprofessor), or just self-learn.
